content:
TouchDevice Class

Definition

Represents a single touch input produced by a finger on a touchscreen.

In this Article

public abstract class TouchDevice : System.Windows.Input.InputDevice, System.Windows.Input.IManipulator
Inheritance
Object
DispatcherObject
System.Windows.Input.InputDevice
TouchDevice

Inherited Members

Equals(Object)
Equals(Object,Object)
GetHashCode()
GetType()
MemberwiseClone()
ReferenceEquals(Object,Object)
ToString()
CheckAccess()
Dispatcher
VerifyAccess()

Remarks

You typically access a TouchDevice by using the TouchDevice property. A TouchDevice represents a single touch on a screen. If multiple touches are present, use the Id property to distinguish between them.

Note

This class contains an inheritance demand at the class level that applies to all members. A SecurityException is thrown when the derived class does not have full-trust permission. For more information about security demands, see Link Demands and Inheritance Demands.

Constructors

TouchDevice(Int32)

Called from constructors in derived classes to initialize the TouchDevice class.

protected TouchDevice (int deviceId);
deviceId
Int32

A unique identifier for the touch device.

Properties

ActiveSource

Gets the PresentationSource that is reporting input for this device.

public override sealed System.Windows.PresentationSource ActiveSource { get; }
Value
PresentationSource

The source that is reporting input for this device.

Captured

Gets the element that captured the TouchDevice.

public System.Windows.IInputElement Captured { get; }
Value
IInputElement

The element that captured the TouchDevice.

CaptureMode

Gets the capture policy of the TouchDevice.

public System.Windows.Input.CaptureMode CaptureMode { get; }
Value
CaptureMode

The capture policy of the TouchDevice.

DirectlyOver

Gets the element that the touch contact point is directly over.

public System.Windows.IInputElement DirectlyOver { get; }
Value
IInputElement

The element that the touch contact point is directly over.

Id

Gets the unique identifier of the TouchDevice, as provided by the operating system.

public int Id { get; }
Value
Int32

The unique identifier of the TouchDevice.

Remarks

A TouchDevice represents a single touch on a screen. If multiple touches are present, use the Id property to distinguish between them.

IsActive

Gets a value that indicates whether the device is active.

public bool IsActive { get; }
Value
Boolean

true if the device is active; otherwise, false.

Target

Gets the element that receives input from the TouchDevice.

public override sealed System.Windows.IInputElement Target { get; }
Value
IInputElement

The element that receives input from the TouchDevice.

Methods

Activate()

Adds the TouchDevice to the input messaging system.

protected void Activate ();
Exceptions
InvalidOperationException

The device is already activated.

Remarks

Classes that inherit from TouchDevice should call this method to activate the current device.

Capture(IInputElement)

Captures a touch to the specified element by using the CaptureMode capture mode.

public bool Capture (System.Windows.IInputElement element);
element
IInputElement

The element that captures the touch input.

Returns
Boolean

true if the element was able to capture the touch; otherwise, false.

Exceptions
ArgumentException

element is not a UIElement, UIElement3D, or ContentElement.

Remarks

A TouchDevice cannot be captured to an element if it is already captured to another element.

Capture(IInputElement,CaptureMode)

Captures a touch to the specified element by using the specified CaptureMode.

public bool Capture (System.Windows.IInputElement element, System.Windows.Input.CaptureMode captureMode);
element
IInputElement

The element that captures the touch.

captureMode
CaptureMode

The capture policy to use.

Returns
Boolean

true if the element was able to capture the touch; otherwise, false.

Exceptions
ArgumentException

element is not a UIElement, UIElement3D, or ContentElement.

Remarks

A TouchDevice cannot be captured to an element if it is already captured to another element.

Deactivate()

Removes the TouchDevice from the input messaging system.

protected void Deactivate ();
Exceptions
InvalidOperationException

The device is not activated.

Remarks

Classes that inherit from TouchDevice should call this method to deactivate the current device.

A TouchLeave event is raised without the corresponding TouchUp event.

GetIntermediateTouchPoints(IInputElement)

When overridden in a derived class, returns all touch points that are collected between the most recent and previous touch events.

public abstract System.Windows.Input.TouchPointCollection GetIntermediateTouchPoints (System.Windows.IInputElement relativeTo);
relativeTo
IInputElement

The element that defines the coordinate space.

Returns
TouchPointCollection

All touch points that were collected between the most recent and previous touch events.

GetTouchPoint(IInputElement)

Returns the current position of the touch device relative to the specified element.

public abstract System.Windows.Input.TouchPoint GetTouchPoint (System.Windows.IInputElement relativeTo);
relativeTo
IInputElement

The element that defines the coordinate space.

Returns
TouchPoint

The current position of the touch device relative to the specified element.

OnCapture(IInputElement,CaptureMode)

Called when a touch is captured to an element.

protected virtual void OnCapture (System.Windows.IInputElement element, System.Windows.Input.CaptureMode captureMode);
element
IInputElement

The element that captures the touch input.

captureMode
CaptureMode

The capture policy.

Remarks

The OnCapture method has no default implementation. It can be overridden in a derived class to perform any actions that are required when the touch input is captured.

OnManipulationEnded(Boolean)

Called when a manipulation has ended.

protected virtual void OnManipulationEnded (bool cancel);
cancel
Boolean

true to cancel the action; otherwise, false.

OnManipulationStarted()

Called when a manipulation is started.

protected virtual void OnManipulationStarted ();

Remarks

The OnManipulationStarted method has no default implementation. It can be overridden in a derived class to perform any actions that are required when touch manipulation is started.

ReportDown()

Reports that a touch is pressed on an element.

protected bool ReportDown ();
Returns
Boolean

true if the TouchDown event was handled; otherwise, false.

Remarks

Classes that inherit from TouchDevice should call this method to raise the TouchDown event. A TouchEnter event is raised before the TouchDown event.

ReportMove()

Reports that a touch is moving across an element.

protected bool ReportMove ();
Returns
Boolean

true if the TouchMove event was handled; otherwise, false.

Remarks

Classes that inherit from TouchDevice should call this method to raise the TouchMove event.

ReportUp()

Reports that a touch was lifted from an element.

protected bool ReportUp ();
Returns
Boolean

true if the TouchUp event was handled; otherwise, false.

Remarks

Classes that inherit from TouchDevice should call this method to raise the TouchUp event. A TouchLeave event is raised after the TouchUp event.

SetActiveSource(PresentationSource)

Sets the PresentationSource that is reporting input for this device.

protected void SetActiveSource (System.Windows.PresentationSource activeSource);
activeSource
PresentationSource

The source that reports input for this device.

Synchronize()

Forces the TouchDevice to synchronize the user interface with underlying touch points.

public void Synchronize ();

Remarks

Synchronizing the user interface with the underlying touch positions might cause TouchMove events to be raised.

Events

Activated

Occurs when the TouchDevice is added to the input messaging system.

public event EventHandler Activated;

Deactivated

Occurs when the TouchDevice is removed from the input messaging system.

public event EventHandler Deactivated;

Updated

Occurs when a touch message is sent.

public event EventHandler Updated;

Explicit Interface Implementations

IManipulator.GetPosition(IInputElement)

Returns the position of the IManipulator object.

System.Windows.Point IManipulator.GetPosition (System.Windows.IInputElement relativeTo);
relativeTo
IInputElement

The element to use as the frame of reference for calculating the position of the IManipulator.

Returns
Point

The position of the IManipulator object.

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the TouchDevice instance is cast to an IManipulator interface.

IManipulator.Id

Gets the unique identifier of the TouchDevice as provided by the operating system.

int System.Windows.Input.IManipulator.Id { get; }
Returns
Int32

The unique identifier of the TouchDevice.

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the TouchDevice instance is cast to an IManipulator interface.

IManipulator.ManipulationEnded(Boolean)

Occurs when a manipulation has ended.

void IManipulator.ManipulationEnded (bool cancel);
cancel
Boolean

true to cancel the action; otherwise, false.

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the TouchDevice instance is cast to an IManipulator interface.
